awd_titl_txt: CPS: TTP Option: Medium: Discovering and Resolving Anomalies in Smart Cities
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding complex activity due to humans and vehicles in a large environment like a city neighborhood or even an entire city is one of the main goals of smart cities. The activities are heterogeneous, distributed, vary over time and mutually interact in many ways, making them hard to capture and understand and mitigate issues in a timely manner. While there has been tremendous progress in capturing aggregate statistics that helps in traffic and city management as well as personal planning and scheduling, much of this work ignores anomalous patterns. Examples include protests, erratic driving, near accidents, construction zone activity, and numerous others. Discovering and resolving anomalies is challenging for many reasons as they are complex and rare, depend on the context and depend on the spatial and temporal extent over which they are observed. There are potentially a large number of anomalies or anomalous patterns, so they are impossible to label and describe manually. 

The PIs will conduct research to address automatic discovery and resolution of anomalous patterns in smart city visual data. The PIs will leverage the large amount of visual data they have access to ranging from cameras at many intersections in Pittsburgh, around the Carnegie Mellon University neighborhood, cameras installed on public buses, and physical distribution networks in the city. The project will include the following four closely integrated research thrusts: (1) Extracting anomalies in the presence of noise due to visual processing algorithms, (2) Automatically discover anomalies at different spatial and temporal scales with intelligent coordinated and distributed planning, (3) discovering the relationship with anomalies and context, and (4) Resolving Anomalies through Hard and Soft Actuation using both automatic and human-in-the-loop methods. 

The work will enable the following applications: Safer and more efficient roads, monitoring the roadway infrastructure and roadside, maximizing the distribution services and informing decisions on health policy (including COVID-19). The project will be conducted in collaboration with several stakeholders - multiple infrastructure and traffic management startups and local city government - in a comprehensive transition to practice program designed to deploy the research in the real world.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit

This project developed novel methods (1) to automatically and remotely calibrate traffic cameras in various countries and zones, (2) for efficient object detection at the edge, (3) for 3D object reconstruction and tracking in traffic scenes by self-supervised learning, (4) to detect people with walking aids, (5) for anomalies of vehicle movement at intersections, (6) for detecting workzones automatically, (7) to detect near-accidents, (8) to augment rare roadwork objects with synthetically generated imagery to help detect them better, (9) to understand road work zone images in cities, (10) to adapt machine learning models that are trained on images captured in common conditions (day and clear weather) to rarer conditions such as poor weather and poor lighting. 

The project included significant efforts in collecting datasets that are or will soon be released publicly for inspiring future research. These datasets include (i) curated image data from 19 US cities of nearly 5000 workzones, (ii) data captured using dashcams of driving in poor weather and lighting conditions, (iii) data collections captured from cameras in buses, (iv) public traffic camera data from many locations installed in Pittsburgh. To protect privacy, the data released have faces and license plates blurred using automated methods.

The work conducted in this project will improve performances of AI systems in poor weather conditions, work zones, and other uncommon/anomolous situations. The application of the developed methods to transportation and smart cities applications shows promising results that would be advantageous to these disciplines and ultimately towards improving safety and mobility on the road. As infrastructure becomes readily instrumented with sensors for capturing visual data, the developed methods will become invaluable in understanding normal and anomalous activity.

Broader Impacts

The work conducted in this project was translated to the team participating in a US DOT intersection safety challenge. Two PIs were part of the team that was announced as one of ten winners of the challenge. As part of translational research, the PIs have created community partnerships with the City of Shaler, PA to understand the traffic, pedestrian, school activity related issues they face and to use our approaches to help make decisions that are best suited to them. Two spin-offs related to the research in this project co-founded by PIs were acquired by larger companies, demonstrating the translational impact of the research.

The project supported several graduate students and technical staff and trained them in areas of intelligent transportation, machine learning and computer vision. The project was part of multiple course capstones for the Masters in Computer Vision program. The project provided opportunities for these participants to present their works at conferences, workshops, and to several visitors to the Carnegie Mellon Robotics Institute from industry, government and academia. The project was part of multiple masters and doctoral theses and resulted in several publications, two of which won Best Paper Awards.

One of these awards was for planning for distributing food during the Pandemic: 2022 IDC Smart Cities North America Award, Public Health and Social Services Category - Carnegie Mellon University (Karen Lightman, Stephen F. Smith, Zachary B. Rubinstein) and Allegheny County, PA: Utilizing School Bus Routes and Machine Learning to Deliver Meals to Families in Need. 

Public transportation is particularly important for economically disadvantaged people and people who are unable to use a car because of age, disability, or mental health problems. A system developed in the future based on this project would make public transportation more efficient and can identify problems like inaccessible bus stops because snow was not removed.
